climbs.name: A Hard Rain's Gonna Fall
climbs.fa: Stewart Green, Mike Heinrichs, and Sherry Heinrichs, 2006

content.description: There are tricky moves both above and below the first bolt. It looks a bit easier than it actually climbs. After the first two bolts, just continue to the top.
content.location: The route is the last route on the right in the area.  Rap the route.

content.description: While this route appears to be a bolted crack (and climbs like a crack in places), there is much less natural protection than one would expect, making its sport-climb status pretty reasonable. Start by climbing through slightly fractured rock for two bolts to a stance below the crack feature. Jam, stem, and even chimney your way up the initial crack to where it jogs right to the arete. Finish up the arete to the anchors below the large roof.
content.protection: Five bolts and anchors. The route would go on natural gear but would be fairly run out as such.
content.location: On the far right side of the Icebox under a large roof; the second-to-last route you encountered on the wall.

content.description: Climb a right-facing corner under a roof/chimney. Step right under the roof, and pull over it and left to a good ledge.  Start clipping some bolts up the thin face to anchors.  It is well protected, fun, and worthwhile.
content.protection: Couple small finger pieces and a #1-2 Camalot for the roof. 3 draws and an anchor.
content.location: It is the furthest left route on the Middle section of The Icebox.  It starts on top of some big boulders.

climbs.name: Tenth Avenue Freeze-Out
climbs.fa: Bob D'Antonio, Kelly Baldwin and Brad Short

content.description: This is the first route that breached the overhanging section of the cliff. Follow the trail along the wall and through the willow trees to the upper section of the wall. On the left edge of the that wall is a steep black wall leading up to some wild looking fins of rock. The route start here. Stick clip the first bolt and fire up a series of hard moves to stance below the fins.Maybe harder for shorter folks. Climb up past two bolts making some wild moves on the fin. Step left and climb/chimmey up between two fins reaching the anchor.
content.protection: Six bolts will get you to a two-bolt anchor. Stick clip the first bolt.

content.description: Begin above a large, broken flake on an arete. Climb the arete, and pull the crux bulge to reach an undercling and cruiser dihedral to the chains.
content.location:
Left of

Hemisphere

, begin on a broken flake and arete. Rappel.

content.description:
As the name implies (at least to those who played early '90s video games), this route requires some Mortal Combat-style karate chop hand jams. With two bolts and bomber gear in between, Sub-Zero is one of the better (and possibly hardest?) traditional routes in Eleven-Mile.

Begin off a cheater stone, and climb slightly crumbly rock (a bit of a theme for the Icebox) up a flake, then undercling right through a roof to a stance below a trio of cracks up the bulging wall. Clip a fixed stopper and bust up and left via the "Mortal Combat" toss into the leftmost crack. Continue up with powerful moves on terrible jams to the anchor at the lip.
content.protection: A bolt protects the start (stick clip recommended), and another protects the final moves. In between, one will need a single set of cams from purple TCU to hand-sized. Lower from bolts and chains.

content.description:
Named in honor of dorm residents everywhere, the Microfridge is a varied route that climbs a direct line through the steepest part of the north face of the Icebox.

The Microfridge starts with a lieback flake and moves through a small roof to a conspicuous and somewhat frustrating, right-leaning seam. Above this, climb through some more lieback moves to a bouldery sequence over the bulge. Finish with a fun tufa-like pillar to anchors on a slab.

For full disclosure, this route is still cleaning up. I tried to get the key features as clean as possible, but there is a good amount of potato chip flakes still on the faces.
content.protection: 7 bolts to a chain lowering anchor. A stick clip might be useful. Bring a few thin hands cams if you want to build a belay on the narrow ledge.
content.location:
The Microfridge climbs through the steep face and roof on the right side of the Icebox's north face, about 20 feet right of

Brain Freeze

. To access, hike way right (all the way to the start of

10th Avenue Freeze Out

), drop your pack, and scramble around left on the ledge about 25 ft. Alternatively, one can climb the 5.6 pitch of

Brain Freeze

and move right up the ledge.

content.description:
This route has got to be one of the better hard sport climbs in the South Platte, if not the whole Front Range. While there are still some potato chip flakes that will clean up with more traffic, the route is very aesthetic and demands good fitness, creative technique, and very precise footwork on solid rock.

Start with slightly awkward, scrunchy moves off the ground to a vertical face with long moves on crimps and sidepulls. Cop a rest, and then traverse right (even climbing downward for a move). Do a powerful and highly technical boulder problem over a bulge to reach a jug and a short slab section. At the top of the slab, rest up again for the heartbreaking final boulder problem to the anchors.
content.location: The right-trending climb up the middle of the steep west face of the Icebox.

content.description:
This is a neat, little route that looks easy, then 'seams' tougher than it looks, and then ultimately ends up being somewhat in the middle of those extremes.

Begin on the right side of the cave, with fun climbing that arcs up and left to get past the first bolt. Cool, technical, flared seam climbing gets you through the next 2 bolts and deposits you at a short runout section. This looks a little daunting, but the climbing unfolds nicely to get you to the 4th bolt. Traverse right past a bolt, and then go straight up through a hand crack/bulge boulder problem that is protected by a bolt.

This little route deserves to get more traffic. It is fun, has a nice, little staging cave, and has zero approach. Do it!
content.protection: 6 bolts and anchors. A hand-sized piece (#1 or #2 Camalot) can be used at the upper bulge to get to the last bolt. Really small gear could possible be used in the flared seam if wanted.
content.location: This is the leftmost route on The Icebox. It is directly above a perfect staging area cave.

content.description:
Ice Age shares the start and first two bolts with

Tenth Avenue Freeze-Out

then cuts right into a large dihedral. This dihedral is full of all manners of shit, which you cannot see from the ground and must grovel through to continue the climb. A long horizontal takes you out of shitland, and a few jugs take you up to easier, more fun terrain.
content.location:
This shares the bouldery start with

Tenth Avenue Freeze-Out

, on the left side of the routes that start on the upper face.

content.description: This is a great climb up the face, a few flakes, and along the left side of a jutting prow to a nice, bowl-shaped ledge with two anchors (see photo).
content.protection: 7 bolts to a 2-bolt anchor. You could also use some small cams in the flakes -- but the bolts are exceptionally well placed. Whoever put this route up did an fantastic job!
content.location:
This is basically in the middle of The Icebox -- just behind and a little to the right of the tall pine tree.  Scramble up a rock ramp to the start, which is a little to the left of the anchors above.  I highly recommend Stewart Green's new "

Rock Climbing Colorado

(2010)" guidebook for details on the climbs at the Icebox.

content.description: This outstanding route climbs the steep arete on the far uphill end of the Icebox. It starts on a low overhang and climbs up a slab to the steep prow. Creativity will no doubt be an asset on this climb - the beta is surprisingly hard to figure out.
content.location: This is on the far right, uphill end of of the Icebox. It's the third route from the end on the right side of the wall.

content.description: Starts on the left side of the cliff near a small cave-like hole. Climb up just right of the cave to the first bolt, traverse out right (yellow alien) to the second bolt. Make hard slab moves reaching a ledge (yellow alien) Make a couple of steep moves past the last bolt, reaching a right-leaning corner. Climb the corner (gear) to a two-bolt anchor anchor. Great route!
content.protection: Eight quickdraws and small to medium gear will get you to a two-bolt anchor.

content.description: Start about 15 feet right of "Ice on the Moon". Climb up to the first bolt, make a stiff move and then fire up past two more bolt to a ledge. Climb up the steep face past two more bolts to a small overhang. Clip a bolt and hump onto the whale tail. Several delicate slab moves take up past several past three more bolt to the anchor. A great lead by Kelly. Good route and like the others on this wall will only get better with more ascents.
content.protection: Nine clips will get you to a two bolt anchor.

content.description:
This is the first pitch of

Brain Freeze

but is listed separately in

11 Miles to Freedom

. From that guide: "Interesting, well protected slab moves over great stone make this one of the best of its grade in the canyon!" I agree, no other sport route in the canyon at this grade is this cool! My 8 year old said maybe

Counter Strike

on 11 Mile Dome (his personal favorite).
content.location:
See the picture for

Hemisphere

. This climb is on the bolted slab to the west of that climb.

content.description:
This route is located just above the lower slab area where the wall turns to vertical at a flat grassy area.

Climb a short slab pitch (5.6)to a two-bolt fixe anchor. Step right from the anchor a make a couple of hard moves up to a ledge. Fire straight up using a large flake on the right and thin crack on the left. Stem wide and up to a short traverse right to a good stance. Fire up steep wall clipping two more bolts and reach the anchor. Caution: a 60 meter rope will not reach the ground.

I did the route in one pitch but can easily be done in two.
content.protection: Fifteen quickdraws will get you to the anchor.

content.description: Climb easy thin hands in a corner on gear to a roof with a bolt. Two more bolts get you to the chains. The crux is pulling the roof. This is short and powerful, with a cool dynamic move to a big jug - I'd say it is definitely worth doing if you're in the area.
content.protection: Two or three pieces in the 0.5-1 range, three bolts, and chains at the top.
content.location:
It ascends the corner just right of

Queen Byron

.
